data: A responsive on-screen keyboard control component.
title: Keyboard

data: When the attach-mode attribute is set to 'attribute' on the Keyboard, then the Keyboard will only react to supported inputs with the data-omni-keyboard-attach attribute without a value.
title: Keyboard

data: When the attach-mode attribute is set to 'id' on the Keyboard, then it will only react to supported inputs with the data-omni-keyboard-attach attribute set equal to the Keyboard's id.
title: Keyboard

data:
When the enterkeyhint attribute is set on a supported input, the Keyboard's call to action button will react to it accordingly. It is supported as follows:
  • 'enter' (Default) - The action-enter slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, the value defined with the action-label attribute on the keyboard will be displayed on the call to action button.
  • 'go' - The action-go slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, a right arrow icon will be displayed by default.
  • 'done' - The action-done slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, a checkmark icon will be displayed by default.
  • 'next' - The action-next slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, an icon of a right arrow within a circle will be displayed by default.
  • 'previous' - The action-previous slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, an icon of a left arrow within a circle will be displayed by default. The Keyboard's default behaviour of focusing the next tabIndex will also reverse to focus the previous instead.
  • 'search' - The action-search slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, a magnifying glass icon will be displayed by default.
  • 'send' - The action-send slot will apply to the call to action button. If not provided, a paper plane icon will be displayed by default.
title: Keyboard

data:
The Keyboard supports masking of the input value on the display preview. Masking will apply to the following:
  • Any elements with the data-omni-keyboard-mask attribute .
  • Any supported web component with the type attribute set to 'password' on their internal <input> elements.
  • Any supported web component utilising data-omni-keyboard-mask on their internal <input> elements.
title: Keyboard

data: When the data-omni-keyboard-no-display attribute is set on a supported input, the display preview on the Keyboard header will not be visible.
title: Keyboard

data: When the data-omni-keyboard-hidden attribute is set on a supported input, the Keyboard will not apply to that input.
title: Keyboard

data: The Keyboard will react accordingly to the data-omni-keyboard-mode attribute on supported target elements.
title: Keyboard

data: The Keyboard supports vanilla native HTML <input> and <textarea> elements.
title: Keyboard

data: Custom rich html can be slotted to fully customize the contents displayed within the <omni-toast>. This can be used to apply extra styling and functionality.
title: Toast

data:
Custom rich html can be slotted in the 'prefix' slot to customize the contents before the <omni-toast> content.

For any specific 'type' this will replace its icon that is shown.
title: Toast

data: Add a close button to the <omni-toast>.
title: Toast

data: Custom rich html can be slotted in the 'close' slot to customize the close button for the <omni-toast>.
title: Toast

data:
Set the display type of the <omni-toast>.


The 'type' attribute supports the following options:

  • 'success' - Green themed toast with a checkmark icon to indicate success.
  • 'warning' - Orange themed toast with a yield icon to indicate warning.
  • 'error' - Red themed toast with an exclamation icon to indicate error.
  • 'info' - Blue themed toast with an information icon to indicate info.
  • 'none' - Default themed toast with no icon. (Default)
title: Toast

data: A toast container that animates in and stacks toast elements.
title: Toast Stack

data:
Display slotted <omni-toast> elements in order.

Slotted toasts can be configured to auto-close after specified milliseconds with the data-toast-duration attribute, after which they will be removed from the parent element.

Slotted toasts with the closeable attribute will be removed from the parent element when their close-click event gets fired (usually via click of the close button).
title: Toast Stack

data:
Create new <omni-toast> elements from script.

Toasts can be configured to auto-close after specified milliseconds with the duration property, after which they will be removed from the parent element.

Toasts with the closeable property will be removed from the parent element when their close-click event gets fired (usually via click of the close button).

All <omni-toast> attributes can be configured as well as additional render functions that can bed provided for slotted content on the toasts.
title: Toast Stack

data:
Create an <omni-toast-stack> instance from script.

An important consideration to keep in mind when using authoring the element via html is that in order for the element to properly overlay all other content, it needs to be a root level element to avoid z-index related issues.

Creating the <omni-toast-stack> via script as in this example can help avoid this issue as it by default parents the newly created instance to the document body. The parent can still be specified to be a different element, however the same considerations will then apply.
title: Toast Stack

data:
Position <omni-toast> elements in the stack.


The 'position' attribute supports the following options:

  • 'top'
  • 'bottom' (Default)
  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'top-left'
  • 'top-right'
  • 'bottom-left'
  • 'bottom-right'
title: Toast Stack

data:
Reverse <omni-toast> elements in the stack.

By default newest toasts are showed at the bottom of the stack. When reversed, newest toasts are showed on top of the stack.
title: Toast Stack
Getting Started
data: You can use Omni Components via CDN or by installing it locally.
The easiest way to install Omni Components is with the CDN:
üí° If you're only using a few components, it will be more efficient to [cherry pick](#cherry-picking-) the ones you need.
You can also install Omni Components locally with the following command:

With the latest package installed from NPM, [you can use a bundler](#bundling-). The ESM package used for [CDN Installation](#cdn-installation-(easiest)-) has its dependencies bundled already which allows it to be used without the need to install dependencies. However when using the local installation from NPM, the dependencies need to be provided externally, or you would need to [bundle the dependencies](#bundling-).

üí° For clarity, the docs will usually show imports from `@capitec/omni-components`. If you're not using a module resolver or bundler, you'll need to adjust these paths to point to the folder Omni Components is in.

The CDN approach is the _easiest_ way to load Omni Components, but easy isn't always efficient. You'll incur the full size of the library even if you only use a handful of components. This is convenient for prototyping or if you're using most of the components, but it may result in longer load times in production. To improve this, you can cherry pick the components you need.

Cherry picking can be done from your local install or [directly from the CDN](https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@capitec/omni-components@esm/). This will limit the number of files the browser has to download and reduce the amount of bytes being transferred. The disadvantage is that you need to load components manually.
Here's an example that loads only the button component.
NOTE: Some components may have dependencies that are automatically imported when you cherry pick.

üí°  _Never_ cherry pick components or utilities from `omni-components.js` as this will still cause the browser to load the entire library. Instead, cherry pick from specific modules as shown above. You will also see files named `chunk.[hash].js` in the `chunks-js` directory, never import these files directly, as they are generated and change from version to version.

Omni Components is distributed as a collection of standard ES modules that [all modern browsers can understand](https://caniuse.com/es6-module). However, importing a lot of modules can result in a lot of HTTP requests and potentially longer load times. Using a CDN can alleviate this, but some users may wish to further optimize their imports with a bundler.
To use Omni Components with a bundler, first install it from NPM along with your bundler of choice:

üí° Using a bundler will allow for optimal [tree shaking](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Tree_shaking), which will ensure the smallest size and most efficient usage. Our [starter templates](#starter-templates-) already provide this for you!

React makes some assumptions about HTML elements that don't fully apply to custom elements, as it treats lower-case tag names differently from upper-case component names in ways that can make custom elements harder than necessary to use.
Omni Components provides a separate package with each web component wrapped into a React component.
You can install Omni Components for React locally with the following command:
Or you can use Omni Components for React directly via a CDN:

import { OmniButton } from "https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/@capitec/omni-components-react@esm/button/index.js";

const App = () => <OmniButton label='Click' type='primary'/>;

By default, Vue will attempt to resolve a non-native HTML tag as a registered Vue component before falling back to rendering it as a custom element. 
This means that in order for custom web components like Omni Components to behave correctly, Vue needs to be made aware that they are custom elements and not Vue components.

Additionally, Vue makes some assumptions regarding property naming, which does not alway apply to custom elements like Omni Components.
Vue expects bound properties to be `kebab-case` named, which means by default `camelCase` named properties will have incorrect bindings.
Use the `:kebab-prop.camel` syntax in order to enforce `camelCase` bindings. See the [`.camel` modifier for `v-bind`](https://vuejs.org/api/built-in-directives.html#v-bind) for more detail.
For example: To bind to a property named `renderItem` with Vue, the property would be bound as `:render-item.camel`.
Refer to [Vue and Web Components](https://vuejs.org/guide/extras/web-components.html#using-custom-elements-in-vue) for additional context on Vue support for custom elements.
To help bootstrap a development project, we offer the following application starter template repositories:

title: Contributing
data: Welcome! We encourage contributions and here's a few important guidelines we would like you to follow:
Please read and follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/capitec/omni-components/blob/develop/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).
Engagement always starts with an Issue where conversations and debates can occur around [bugs](#bugs) and [feature requests](#feature-requests):
**Do** search for a similar / existing Issue prior to submitting a new one.
**Do not** use issues for any personal support. Use [Discussions](https://github.com/capitec/omni-components/discussions) or [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/) instead.
**Do not** side-track or derail issues threads. Stick to the topic please.
**Do not** post comments using just "+1", "++" or "üëç". Use [Reactions](https://github.blog/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) instead.
A bug is an error, flaw or fault associated with *any part* of the project:
**Do** search for a similar / existing Issue prior to submitting a new one.
**Do** describe the bug concisely, **avoid** adding extraneous code, logs or screenshots.
**Do** attach a minimal test or repro (e.g. [CodePen](https://codepen.io/), [jsFiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/)) to demonstrate the bug.
A feature request is an improvement or new capability associated with *any part* of the project:
**Do** search for a similar / existing Issue prior to submitting a new one.
**Do** provide sufficient motivation / use case(s) for the feature.
**Do not** submit multiple unrelated requests within one request.
üí° TIP: We suggest that you engage as much as possible within an Issue prior to proceeding with any contributions.
A vulnerability is typically a security-related risk associated with *any part* of the project (or any dependencies):
**Do** refer to our [Security Policy](https://github.com/capitec/omni-components/security/policy) for more info.
**Do not** report any Issues or mention in public Discussions for discretionary purposes.
`develop` - Default branch for all Pull Requests.
`main` - Stable branch for all periodic releases.
VS Code + recommended extensions (recommended, but not required).
[Fork](https://github.com/capitec/omni-components/fork) the repository and create a branch from `develop`.
Clone the forked repo, checkout your branch, and run `npm ci` inside the repository root.
Start up the dev server with `npm run serve` (or by launching debugging in VS Code).
Install the testing dependencies with `npx playwright install --with-deps`.
When adding or editing components, please note the following key directories:

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ button
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Button.stories.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Button.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.ts
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
`src` - Contains all components in a flat structure, each named after a component, e.g. `button`. Contents:
`Button.ts` - The component. *(NOTE: There might be multiple, depending on complexity and composition)*
`index.ts` - The directory-level index, containing one or more component exports.
`README.md` - The README for the component *(NOTE: Generated when Pull Request is merged)*.
**Do** use *lower case* [kebab-case](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letter_case#Kebab_case) for component folder names, e.g. `some-component`. üç¢
**Do** use uppercase first letter [CamelCase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camel_case) for component file names, e.g. `SomeComponent.ts`.
**Do** use the name of the component, suffixed with `.stories` for component story file names, e.g. `SomeComponent.stories.ts`.
**Do** match component name with its file name, e.g. `SomeComponent.ts` contains `export class SomeComponent { ... }`.
**Do** prefix the custom element name with `omni-`.
**Do not** use any verbs or prefixes within component property names, instead **do** use nouns, e.g. `mode`, `position`.
**Do** name CSS custom properties as follows:
üí° TIP: Refer to existing components and stories for examples.
Here's a *non-exhaustive* list of requirements that are key to contributing to this project.
**Do** implement "mobile first" templates, leveraging [Responsive Design](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/CSS_layout/Responsive_Design) layout and styling principles. üì±
**Do** utilize [LitElement's](https://lit.dev/) [decorators](https://lit.dev/docs/components/decorators/), required for element and property names.
**Do** ensure sufficient [JSDoc](https://jsdoc.app/) as well as general code comments are added.
**Do** use and extend existing shared CSS component and theme custom properties. (See [`src/core/OmniElement.ts`](https://github.com/capitec/omni-components/blob/develop/src/core/OmniElement.ts))
**Do** set suitable CSS custom property defaults, **avoid** hard-coding CSS property values directly within components, unless deemed required.
**Do** adhere to and leverage existing DOM standards when making use of [`<input>`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLInputElement) element.
**Do** allow components to be user customizable via [slot](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/slot) implementations.
**Do** implement only *one* component class within a component file.
**Do** implement a [play function](https://github.com/capitec/omni-components/blob/develop/src/utils/PlayFunction.ts) per story to test story-specific component state and event behaviors.
**Do** set the `data-testid` within every story template.
**Do** ensure that stories are authored to be both dark and light theme friendly (test via the hosted documentation).
**Do** maintain each built-in theme, by ensuring all `--omni-theme-*` CSS custom properties are implemented.
**Do** test each theme thoroughly via the hosted documentation.
üí° TIP: Refer to existing components, stories and themes for examples for any of the above.
**Do** ensure the branch is up to date with the `develop` branch.
**Do** ensure there's no conflicts with the `develop` branch.
üí° TIP: Analyze changes locally with `npm run lint`.
üí° TIP: Apply changes locally with `npm run format`.
All story play function tests pass.
üí° TIP: Run tests locally with `npm run test`.
<!--- * All story play function tests has at least 80% code coverage of components. --->
